fields.descriptive_line: Drawing of the Chiesa di S. Simon e Guida Apostoli, Venice, 18th century, in an album commissioned by the Earl of Bute
fields.physical_description: Drawing of the Chiesa di S. Simon e Guida Apostoli, in pen and ink and watercolour, on paper. It depicts the facade of the building with Corinthian columns and a pediment carved with low relief. At the bottom of the page is a plan indicating the placement of each of the columns and the stairs leading up to the entrance. The drawing is in a portrait format and is bound in the album.
fields.materials_techniques: Pen and ink and watercolour on paper
fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level D, case ABOVE 115LL, box LL.30
fields.marks:
Pianta e alzato della loggia nella facciata della chiesa di SS. Simeon e Giuda Apostoli - ditto di San Simeon Piccolo
Architettura di di Giovanni Scalfaroto Veneto  Plan and elevation plan of the church of SS. Simeon and Giuda Apostoli's facade called San Simeon Piccolo
Architecture by Giovanni Scalfaroto, Venetian

fields.location: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level D

fields.name: Prints & Drawings Study Room, level D

fields.public_access_description:
The Church of San Simeon Piccolo was founded in the IXth century however the current building was rebuilt, in 1738, after a design by the architect Giovanni Antonio Scalfarotto (1718-1738) who was inspired by the Pantheon in Rome. He also added Veneto-Byzantine metal-covered dome and a Palladio-influenced temple front decorated with a marble low relief by Francesco Cabianca (1665-1737). The drawing shows the façade front door surmounted by a pediment behind a series of Corinthian columns supporting a large pediment decorated with figures in low-relief. A receding squared structure surmounts the façade. A floor-plan beneath the façade shows the interior structure with the placement of the columns and stairs.The egg-shaped dome and long flight of stairs leading up to the entrance are reminiscent of the Church of the Salute.

Antonio Visentini (Venice, 21 Nov 1688 – Venice, 26 June 1782) was an Italian painter, engraver, architect and theorist. He was first known as a painter and trained with the Venetian history painter Giovanni Antonio Pellegrini (1675-1741). He became known as an engraver by the end of the 1720s when he was commissioned by Joseph Smith to produce engravings of Canaletto’s views of Venice. Visentini started working as an architect in 1731, and his first theoretical work, Libro di Architettura, which included Rococo-influenced drawings by Pier Antonio Morelli after Visentini’s ideas, was published in 1733. 

His ideas on contemporary architecture derived from Antiquity and the work of Andrea Palladio (1508-80). Later however, Visentini developed neo-Palladian and anti-Baroque ideas. Visentini and his pupils executed numerous drawings of ancient and contemporary buildings intended to disseminate exemplary architecture. He participated to the foundation of the Venetian Academy in 1755, where he became a teacher of architectural perspective in 1772.
fields.credit: Accepted by H M Government in lieu of Inheritance Tax and allocated to the Victoria & Albert Museum, 2000
fields.production_note: This drawing has recently been atrributed to Antonio Visentini by Paola Modesti
